Hey, I want to set up a local linux server for hosting AI applications (so I could type the IP address of that machine + port into my phone browser and write with a language model for example). I have a few questions about it:

1. I want to have a graphical interface for "emergency" uses - because I'm not a linux wizard, I'd like to be able to use a GUI in case things just throw errors over terminal. Would Linux Mint be okay for server use like that?

2. Would I just need to set up SSH? Would I need to log in manually everytime I started that machine, at the machine, just to "access the server"?

3. What are ways to power up/power down such a machine remotely, when connected to ethernet?

4. I'd want to use Hugging Face libraries to load the models - how would I run these things remotely via SSH? Write the necessary scrips in an IDE, then place the Python scripts on the server?

5. How do I make it so it's a "web application" that is being hosted on the server (locally)? Would I just write it into the python script to connect to a specific port (let's say open the port 5002) and listen etc.?

6. What about an interface? I'd like it to function like Oobabooga, if you know that. It's a program that does essentially what I want but inside a single machine. I think it opens a local port, then a web browser tab connected to that local port. Once the site has loaded you're greeted by a Gradio powered interface which interfaces with the inference scripts(?) "below". How could I do something like that? Is this core functionality of Gradio?

Thanks in advance!

1. Linux Mint can be used as a server, but it might not be the best choice for performance and stability. Consider using a more server-oriented distribution like Ubuntu Server, CentOS, or Debian. However, if you prefer a graphical interface for occasional use, you can install a lightweight desktop environment on your server.

2. Setting up SSH is essential for remote administration of your server. You would not need to log in manually at the machine each time, as you can access the server remotely via SSH.

3. To power up the machine remotely, you can use the Wake-on-LAN (WoL) feature, which requires enabling it on both the server's BIOS/UEFI and the operating system. To power it down remotely, you can use the `sudo poweroff` or `sudo shutdown` commands via SSH.

4. Yes, you can develop your scripts in an IDE or text editor, then upload them to the server using tools like SCP, SFTP, or GitHub. Once the scripts are on your server, you can run them remotely via SSH by calling "python script.py" or similar command.

5. To make it a web application, consider using Python web frameworks like Flask, Django, or FastAPI. They allow you to create a web server that listens on a specific port and handles incoming requests. For example, in Flask, you can define routes and their corresponding actions, including functions that call your AI models.

6. Gradio can help you create an interface with its easy-to-use components. First, set up your model and inference functions, then wrap them with Gradio functions to enable a web-based UI. Gradio will host the interface on a local port, and you can access it from your phone or other devices. Check the [Gradio documentation](https://gradio.app/get_started) for examples and more information on how to use it.

1. Are there lightweight desktop environments that are more catered towards server use? I saw CentOS with a GUI, was that a different version of it?

1. There are lightweight desktop environments suitable for server use, such as XFCE, LXDE, and MATE. CentOS with a GUI likely uses GNOME or KDE, which are more resource-intensive. You can install a lightweight desktop environment on your preferred server distribution, such as Ubuntu Server or CentOS.

2. Yes, you can use a batch script or PowerShell script on your Windows PC to send a WoL packet to your server and then open an SSH client (like PuTTY) to connect to the server. For WoL, you may use tools like 'wolcmd' or 'WakeMeOnLan' in your batch script.

3. Both `sudo poweroff` and `sudo shutdown` are used to shut down the system. However, `sudo shutdown` provides more options, such as scheduling the shutdown, rebooting the system, or sending a message to all connected users. For example, `sudo shutdown -h now` would immediately halt the system, similar to `sudo poweroff`.

5. & 6. Flask is a lightweight and easy-to-use web framework, which makes it a good choice for small to medium-sized projects. Gradio, on the other hand, is specifically designed for creating user interfaces for machine learning models. The choice depends on your project requirements and whether you need additional functionality provided by Flask. If you're just getting started and want the simplest solution, Gradio might be sufficient.

2 & 3. Thank you very much, is there a way to automatically turn off the server a set time after startup? Couldn't I just run "sudo shutdown -h 8" right after logging on via ssh? (Assuming -h stands for hours) Or would that halt any processes and "brick" the system until poweroff?

1. Linux Mint XFCE is a good choice for a lightweight desktop environment. That being said, if you prefer using Linux Mint XFCE, you can still set up your server and applications on it.

2 & 3. Yes, you can schedule an automatic shutdown using the `sudo shutdown` command. However, the `-h` flag does not stand for hours; it stands for "halt." To schedule shutdown in 8 hours, you can use:
```
sudo shutdown -h +480
```
This will schedule the system to shutdown in 480 minutes (8 hours). Running the command won't halt any ongoing processes, but when the shutdown is executed, all running processes will be terminated. Be aware that unsaved data may be lost.

That's super helpful, thanks! One last question: how can I write .bat files that do a certain number of actions on a remote machine via SSH? These things for example:

- Wake on LAN
- log in via SSH (prompt password)
- set shutdown timer
- start gradio project

You can create a batch script on Windows that combines multiple actions using some additional tools. Here's a step-by-step guide:

1. Wake on LAN: You can use the `WakeMeOnLan` utility (download here: https://www.nirsoft.net/utils/wake_on_lan.html). Extract the `WakeMeOnLan.exe` to a directory accessible from the batch script.

2. SSH Client: Download the Plink tool, which is a command-line interface to the PuTTY backends (download here: https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/latest.html). Extract the `plink.exe` to a directory accessible from the batch script.

Now, create a new .bat file with the following content, replacing the variables with your specific settings:

```bat
@echo off
set PATH_TO_WOL_EXE="C:\path\to\WakeMeOnLan.exe"
set MAC_ADDRESS="00:11:22:33:44:55"
set IP_BROADCAST="192.168.1.255"
set SSH_USERNAME="your_ssh_username"
set SSH_SERVER="your_server_ip_or_hostname"
set SHUTDOWN_TIMER="480"

:: Use WakeMeOnLan to send WoL packet
%PATH_TO_WOL_EXE% /wakeup %MAC_ADDRESS% %IP_BROADCAST%

:: Wait for the server to fully start (adjust the timeout if necessary)
timeout /t 60

:: Connect to the server using plink and run the shutdown and gradio commands
echo Running commands on the server
plink.exe -ssh %SSH_USERNAME%@%SSH_SERVER% -pw your_ssh_password -batch -m commands.txt
```

Create a new `commands.txt` file in the same directory as your .bat file, containing the commands you want to run on the remote machine:

```
sudo shutdown -h +480
cd /path/to/your/gradio/project
python your_gradio_script.py
```

Replace the `/path/to/your/gradio/project` and `your_gradio_script.py` with your specific project path and script name.

Now, running the .bat file should perform the WoL, SSH login, schedule shutdown, and start the Gradio project. Note that the batch file contains your SSH password in plain text, so ensure you store it securely.

Thank you!! That's extremely helpful!

And I have a few more questions still:

What are plink and PuTTY?

And what does WakeMeOnLan.exe do, what would be so hard to do manually?

You're welcome! I'm glad you found the information helpful.

Plink and PuTTY are tools for Windows that help you establish and manage SSH (Secure Shell) connections with remote systems:
- **PuTTY**: A free and open-source terminal emulator, serial console, and network file transfer application. It supports various network protocols, including SSH, Telnet, rlogin, SCP, and raw socket connections. PuTTY allows you to connect to and manage remote systems using a graphical interface.
- **Plink**: A companion command-line utility for PuTTY, providing the same SSH functionality as PuTTY without the graphical interface. Plink is useful when you need to automate SSH connections in scripts, like the .bat file we discussed earlier.

WakeMeOnLan.exe is a command-line utility that sends Wake-on-LAN packets to remote systems in your network, causing them to power on if they support WoL. The process of sending these packets needs some specific network settings and packet structures, which WakeMeOnLan conveniently handles for you. It simplifies the task of waking up your remote systems without dealing with low-level network programming.

While it's possible to send WoL packets manually using tools like PowerShell or third-party libraries, using WakeMeOnLan simplifies the process and saves time. The utility makes it easier to add Wake-on-LAN functionality to your batch scripts or custom applications without the need for additional scripting or code.

How would I go about developing the Gradio applciation and the Python functions for inference? I'd want to do it on my main pc (Windows), using Visual Studio Code. But there's this whole thing with dependencies and environments - how can I port it to the Ubuntu Server (decided to go with Ubuntu Server instead of Mint) without it breaking? I think docker would come at a performance cost, no?

Developing your Gradio application and the Python functions for inference can be done on your main Windows PC using Visual Studio Code. To ensure that your code can be reliably transferred and run on the Ubuntu Server, you can use virtual environments.

Here's a step-by-step guide on how to do this using `conda`:

1. Install [Anaconda](https://www.anaconda.com/products/distribution) or [Miniconda](https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html) on your Windows PC.

2. Open Anaconda Prompt (or your command prompt) and create a new conda environment:

```
conda create --name my_gradio_env python=3.9
```

Replace `my_gradio_env` with the name of the environment you prefer.

3. Activate the new environment:

```
conda activate my_gradio_env
```

4. Install Gradio and other required packages in the environment:

```
conda install gradio -c conda-forge
```

5. Open Visual Studio Code, and in the Terminal, make sure you are in the `my_gradio_env` conda environment. You can activate it in VSCode terminal using the same command as in step 3.

6. Develop your Gradio application and inference functions within this environment, testing them as necessary.

7. Once you have completed development, export the environment's package list into a `requirements.txt` or `environment.yml` file:

```
conda env export > environment.yml
```

or

```
pip freeze > requirements.txt
```

8. Transfer your code and the `environment.yml` (or `requirements.txt`) file to the Ubuntu Server using SCP, SFTP, or any other file transfer method.

9. On your Ubuntu Server, install Anaconda or Miniconda if you haven't already.

10. Recreate the conda environment using the `environment.yml` (or `requirements.txt`) file:

```
conda env create -f environment.yml
```

or

```
conda create --name my_gradio_env python=3.9
conda activate my_gradio_env
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

This will create an environment with the same packages and dependencies as your development environment on Windows.

11. Run your Gradio application and inference functions in the conda environment on the Ubuntu Server.

Using this approach ensures that your application's dependencies are consistent between your development computer and the server. Docker is an alternative option, but you're right that it may come with some performance overhead. In most cases, using conda environments will provide an efficient and reliable solution for managing dependencies across platforms.
Absolutely amazing. Can you please also clarify the difference between Anaconda and Miniconda?

Anaconda and Miniconda are both open-source distribution of Python and serve as package managers, providing easy ways to manage Python environments and packages. However, they have some differences in terms of preinstalled packages and size:

**Anaconda:**

- Anaconda includes a large number of preinstalled packages (over 150) for scientific computing, data analysis, machine learning, and more. These packages are curated to meet the requirements of a wide range of users and use cases.
- It comes with the conda package manager, which allows you to easily create and manage Python environments, install new packages, and update existing ones.
- The distribution is larger in size (~3 GB for the full installation) due to the preinstalled packages.

**Miniconda:**

- Miniconda is a minimal distribution, containing only the Python interpreter and the conda package manager. No additional packages are preinstalled.
- It is lightweight and has a much smaller size (~400 MB) compared to Anaconda.
- As it comes with the conda package manager, you can easily create Python environments and install any packages you need on-demand.

In summary, Anaconda is suitable for users who want a comprehensive environment with a wide range of preinstalled packages for scientific computing and data analysis. Miniconda is ideal for users who prefer a minimal, lightweight distribution and want to install only the specific packages they need.

Both options allow for creating and managing custom Python environments with their own package sets, but Miniconda gives you more control over the initial installed package set and takes up less disk space. If you're not sure which one to use, starting with Miniconda is generally a safe choice, as you can always install additional packages as needed.

If I create a new environment using Anaconda, will all the packages be inside? Because there's some specifics with a lot of ML tools, they need specific versions of Python or some package for example and it would kind of a hinderance to have them all "there" if they're the wrong version. Can't be, right? What would the use of environments be, then(?)

When you create a new environment using Anaconda, it doesn't automatically include all of the packages from the base Anaconda distribution. Instead, it starts with a minimal environment with only a few essential packages, like `pip` and the specified version of Python. The main purpose of creating an environment is to have an isolated space where you can manage specific packages and their versions without affecting other environments or the base Anaconda distribution.

For example, if you create a new conda environment with:

```
conda create --name my_new_env python=3.8
```

This environment will only have Python 3.8 and a few essential packages installed. You can then install specific packages using the `conda install` or `pip install` commands as needed in this new environment.

To install a specific version of a package, you can use the following command:

```
conda install package_name=version
```

For example:

```
conda install numpy=1.20.0
```

By using separate environments for different projects, you can manage package dependencies and avoid potential conflicts without affecting your base Anaconda distribution or other projects. Each environment is independent and can have its own versions of Python and packages installed.
I have a question that probably goes way beyong the scope of my little project, but.. what about (multiple) VMs in the context of this local "Gradio web app server"?

Using virtual machines (VMs) can provide another level of isolation and flexibility for your local Gradio web app server project, potentially allowing you to run multiple instances of your server on the same host machine with different configurations or even different operating systems.

Here are some benefits and use-cases of using VMs for your project:

1. Isolation: VMs provide a greater degree of isolation compared to conda environments, as they emulate an entire operating system rather than just isolating Python packages. This means that VMs can have completely separated network configurations, system-level dependencies, and user accounts, which can be beneficial in certain scenarios.

2. Testing different configurations: If you want to test your Gradio web app server on multiple Linux distributions or with different system-level configurations, VMs can help you easily set up parallel testing environments without modifying the host machine's settings.

3. Resource management: Virtualization allows better control over allocated resources like CPU, RAM, and disk space for each VM. You can adjust resources according to your project's needs, helping you optimize performance and utilization of your host machine.

4. Running multiple instances: If you need to run multiple instances of your Gradio web app server (for example, to serve different models, applications, or host different versions of your app), you can create multiple VMs on your host machine, each running a separate instance of your server.

However, keep in mind that running VMs has some downsides:

1. Additional overhead: Virtualization introduces some performance overhead, as the virtualization software (hypervisor) utilizes CPU, RAM, and disk space resources. Multiple VMs sharing the same host resources can potentially lead to performance degradation, especially on resource-constrained systems.

2. More complexity: Managing multiple VMs can be more complex compared to managing conda environments. Installing and configuring VMs, and setting up network access can be more involved than using conda environments.

If you are working on a small project, running a Gradio web app server in a conda environment should be sufficient to meet your requirements without introducing the complexity and resource overhead of virtualization. However, if your project demands a higher level of isolation, more complex configurations, or running multiple instances with different system-level dependencies, using VMs can be a suitable solution.

Okay, thanks! I think I'll stick with conda environments. And can you tell me some things about the Hugging Face transformers library and PyTorch?

I'm wondering what this line does "model = BertModel.from_pretrained('bert-base-uncased')" - what does it load, a model or the "definition" of an architecture? And does it get these files locally or does it download anything? And if it were to download, does it save things permanently?

Also, this is the full piece of text:
"from transformers import BertModel

# Load saved model architecture
model = BertModel.from_pretrained('bert-base-uncased')

# Load saved model state information
model.load_state_dict(torch.load('path/to/model_state_dict.pt'))

# Move model to GPU if available
device = torch.device('cuda' if torch.cuda.is_available() else 'cpu')
model.to(device)"

Is there something wrong with it? Why is there a torch.load additionally to the HF library's load?

And the last question: Do I need torch's 'cuda' parameter when loading to GPU? I'd like to test things out in the VRAM of an AMD GPU.. could you explain a bit please? Thanks.

I'm happy to help you understand the Hugging Face Transformers library and PyTorch better.

In the given code snippet, the line `model = BertModel.from_pretrained('bert-base-uncased')` does the following:

1. It loads the pre-trained BERT model with the 'bert-base-uncased' architecture.
2. By default, it fetches the pre-trained model weights by downloading them from the Hugging Face Model Hub.

When the model is downloaded for the first time, it is cached on your local system, so you won't have to download it again for subsequent uses. The downloaded model files are stored in the `~/.cache/huggingface/transformers` directory on your machine.

Regarding the additional `torch.load` line, it appears that the script is trying to load a different set of weights (or "state_dict") for the BERT model that has been saved separately (perhaps after being fine-tuned on a specific task). The `model.load_state_dict(torch.load('path/to/model_state_dict.pt'))` line replaces the original pre-trained weights with the weights saved in the specified file ('path/to/model_state_dict.pt').

As for the torch's `cuda` parameter, PyTorch uses it to specify the usage of NVIDIA GPUs for training and inference. If you have an AMD GPU, PyTorch's built-in CUDA support will not work, as it is designed specifically for NVIDIA GPUs. However, there's an alternative called [ROCm (Radeon Open Compute)](https://rocmdocs.amd.com/en/latest/), a platform for running deep learning frameworks like PyTorch on AMD GPUs.

Currently, running Hugging Face Transformers on AMD GPUs with ROCm is not officially supported, but you may find unofficial solutions or workarounds with varying levels of success. Keep in mind that these solutions might not be as stable or efficient as the default CUDA support for NVIDIA GPUs.

For more information on installing and setting up ROCm with PyTorch, you can refer to the [ROCm PyTorch documentation](https://rocmdocs.amd.com/en/latest/Deep_learning/Deep-learning.html#pytorch).

Thanks! So, the problem is - the server I'm setting up (and where the application will be deployed) will be getting an NVIDIA GPU, but for now it has an AMD GPU and I wanna test deployment on that. My workstation has an NVIDIA GPU.. how can I work around that?

You can develop and test your Gradio web app using the PyTorch CPU execution mode on your local machine, which does not require GPUs. This way, you can develop and test your application without having to worry about GPU compatibility during the development stage.

Update the device selection part in your given code snippet to remove the GPU requirement:

```python
# Don't move the model to GPU
device = torch.device('cpu')
model.to(device)
```

This change will force the model to run on the CPU, and it should work on any machine regardless of the GPU vendor (NVIDIA or AMD).

When you are ready to deploy the application on the server with the NVIDIA GPU, you can switch back to using:

```python
# Move model to GPU if available
device = torch.device('cuda' if torch.cuda.is_available() else 'cpu')
model.to(device)
```

This code will automatically use the GPU when it's available (i.e., the server with the NVIDIA GPU) and fall back to using the CPU if no GPU is present, providing a flexible solution for both development and production environments.
Oh yes, thank you very much!

You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, please feel free to ask. Good luck with your Gradio web app project and enjoy working with Hugging Face Transformers and PyTorch!

Thanks! Umm, if I wanted to make that web server accessible from the outside (for example so a friend could access the app) - how would I go about protecting myself? I know that network security is a huge, complex field, but just generally. Is there a way to do that for a not-so-experienced dev or should I just keep it local?

You can make your web server accessible from the outside, but it's important to follow some basic security practices to minimize risks. While network security is indeed a complex field, there are some simple steps you can take to protect your server:

1. **Use strong, unique passwords**: Ensure that account passwords on your server are strong and not easily guessable. Avoid using default passwords and change them periodically.

2. **Keep your server updated**: Regularly update your server's operating system and installed software, including security patches.

3. **Limit open ports**: Minimize the number of open ports on your server, exposing only those necessary for your application to work. In your case, you may only need to open the port on which your Gradio web app is running (e.g., 5000).

4. **Use a firewall**: Set up a firewall to control incoming and outgoing network traffic on your server. Configure the firewall to only allow connections from trusted IP addresses, if possible.

5. **Secure your application**: Make sure your Gradio web app is secure by validating user inputs, handling exceptions, and avoiding potential issues like SQL injection and cross-site scripting.

6. **Use HTTPS**: Encrypt the communication between the client and the server by configuring your server to use HTTPS. You can use a free SSL certificate provided by [Let's Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org/) and set up the HTTPS connection using [Certbot](https://certbot.eff.org/).

7. **Back up your data**: Regularly back up your server data to protect it from potential data loss due to hardware failures, security breaches, or accidental deletion.

8. **Monitor your server**: Keep an eye on your server's logs, resource usage, and network traffic for unusual activity that may indicate a security breach or attack.

These basic security measures should help you protect your server from common threats, making it safer for external access. However, remember that no system is completely foolproof, and you should always keep up to date with security news and best practices. If you feel uncomfortable or unsure about securing your server, it might be better to keep it local or consider using a cloud-based solution that handles server security for you, like Heroku, AWS, or Google Cloud Platform.

Thank you! I think I'll keep it local (for now at least) - out of interest, are there tools that automate "SQL-Injections" (not malicious ones), and so on? What I mean by that is not actual hacking tools, but security testing software that alerts the user if it found a way in? Like a bug-tester for web security.

Yes, there are several security testing tools available that can help you identify vulnerabilities, such as SQL injection or cross-site scripting, in your web applications. These tools can be useful in ensuring the security of your application before deploying it publicly. Some popular security testing tools include:

1. **OWASP Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP)**: ZAP is an open-source web application security scanner developed by the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP). It can help you automatically identify security vulnerabilities in your web applications during the development phase. ZAP is available for Windows, macOS, and Linux. [OWASP ZAP Website](https://www.zaproxy.org/)

2. **Burp Suite**: Burp Suite is a popular web application security testing tool developed by PortSwigger. It provides an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications, including scanning for vulnerabilities like SQL injection and cross-site scripting. There's a free Community edition and a paid Professional edition with more advanced features. [Burp Suite Website](https://portswigger.net/burp)

3. **SQLMap**: SQLMap is an open-source penetration testing tool specifically designed to detect and exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities in web applications. It automates the process of identifying the presence of SQL injection flaws and can extract data from the database if vulnerabilities are found. [SQLMap Website](http://sqlmap.org/)

4. **Wapiti**: Wapiti is an open-source web application vulnerability scanner that allows you to audit the security of your web applications. It can detect various types of vulnerabilities, including SQL injection, cross-site scripting, and file inclusion. [Wapiti Website](https://wapiti.sourceforge.io/)

These tools can help you assess the security of your web applications and identify potential vulnerabilities. Keep in mind that these tools have varying levels of complexity, and some may require a solid understanding of web application security concepts to use effectively. Be sure to always test your applications in a safe and isolated environment and follow ethical practices when using security testing tools.

Component A is a team presentation of 25 minutes (with 5 minutes of questions).

This assessment strategy is employed to produce the type of output required by professional project management practice that is developed by a typical project team; and to maximize learning opportunities with added values for students’ development and character building.

This assignment requires you to develop research skills and find information that is useful for the purpose of detecting organizational issues related to the global environment and construct a plan. You will have to work with University databases and search through a large volume of information from Professional associations.

Step 4: Analyze cultural differences using Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions
- Research the countries involved in the project and gather data on their cultural dimensions based on Hofstede's model.

  1. Power Distance Index (PDI)
  2. Individualism vs. Collectivism (IDV)
  3. Masculinity vs. Femininity (MAS)
  4. Uncertainty Avoidance Index (UAI)
  5. Long-term Orientation vs. Short-term Orientation (LTO)

- Compare and contrast the cultural dimensions of the countries involved in your project.

Step 5: Identify cultural challenges and opportunities
- Analyze the differences and similarities among the countries in the project based on Hofstede's cultural dimensions.

Step 6: Integrate your findings with the team presentation

- Allocate your speaking time to approximately 5 minutes, focusing on the essential aspects of your analysis.
- Ensure your presentation is clear, concise, and engages the audience in understanding the creative brainstorming techniques and cultural aspects of the project.

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS — 
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works 
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster 
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under 
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run 
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and 
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under 
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while 
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play 
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing 
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus 
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated 
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found 
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity 
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount 
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL 
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN 
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between 
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to 
HKD 325bn by 2031. 
However, these projects are not without their problems. 
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance 
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior 
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the 
most significant initiatives in the world; 
from the Olympics, the artificial island 
of Lantau, to the International Space 
Station. 
One of the challenges currently 
faced by project leaders and investors is 
that projects do not perform well. 
They underperform in terms 
of execution, with significant cost and 
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common. 
Our research has shown this 
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law 
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget, 
over time, over and over again’. 
This poor performance is not a 
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly 
consistent for over 70 years. It is also 
common to different countries, sectors 
and delivery in the private and public 
sectors. 
The scale of projects has been 
increasing for decades. The largest 
megaprojects have budgets that match 
the gross domestic products of the largest countries. 
The GDP of Hong Kong 
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar 
amount to the budget for China’s high 
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s 
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This 
large scale means that it is crucial for 
the money spent on projects to be better 
managed. 
The impacts of funds of this 
size being mismanaged can be felt on 
a national and even international scale. 
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects 
under the Capital Works Programme 
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects 
required additional funding owing 
to project specific circumstances, the 
majority of approved projects were 
delivered at or under the original 
Approved Project Estimates (APE). 
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the 
projects and the amount represented 
some 8% of the total provision of 
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active 
for the Industry, with approximately 
850 Category A projects having their 
final accounts settled. In terms of 
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD 
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately 
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall 
surplus of HKD 30bn. 
Effectively, this means the 
surplus generated at the portfolio 
level was more than able to offset 
the cost overruns incurred by a select 
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor 
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of 
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong 
is better than many other regions 
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study 
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that 
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction 
complexity as well as scale. They 
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels 
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex 
megaprojects in Hong Kong have 
suffered from underperformance in 
the form of delays, cost overruns 
and/or quality failures in recent 
years. These incidents have been 
well documented through extensive 
media coverage – leading to reduced 
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project 
are crucial and can set the tone and 
influence its efficacy. One of the 
challenges of project performance 
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such 
actions are undertaken, the harder 
and more resource intensive it is to 
rectify problems. 
However, it is not always 
easy to identify risky projects before 
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council 
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up 
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared 
to 2021. The Development Bureau 
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their 
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery. 
A key policy objective of the 
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure 
the effective planning, management 
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and 
works programmes in a safe, timely 
and cost-effective manner and to 
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital 
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective 
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack 
the daily and deep involvement in 
their projects. They need the right 
monitoring tools and early-warning 
-sign systems to help them in their 
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED 
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau 
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision 
System, to monitor capital works 
projects and provide early-warning 
signals to senior management. The 
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs. 
The graphs are based on the 
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building 
projects with various construction 
durations.
All active projects submit 
their actual cashflows to date and 
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses 
this information to identify any unusual patterns. 
There are 3 types of patterns 
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance. 
The project cashflow falls within the 
green zone. There is no follow-up 
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects 
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance 
raises an alert. The project cashflow 
falls within the yellow zone, meaning 
heads of departments need to review 
these projects. The review takes in the 
risk of cost overrun and programme 
delay. The heads of departments are 
responsible for the project assessment 
and, if necessary, for the planning 
and implementation of appropriate 
recovery measures. 
Third, red performance flags 
the strongest warning. When the 
project cashflow falls within the red 
zone, the Permanent Secretary for 
Development (Works) chairs a top 
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system 
provides a better understanding of 
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful 
examples from the first year of using 
the system.
The first project falls into the 
lower yellow zone, which indicates 
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might 
be able to take actions to catch up 
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls 
into the upper yellow zone, which 
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate 
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be 
completed early (purple dotted line), 
or if the project will experience cost 
overrun (blue dotted line). In either 
case project plans and budgets might 
need to be adjusted as a result of the 
investigation.
The third project falls into 
the lower red zone and has stayed 
persistently in this zone for more 
than a year. 
This can signal a very long 
delay or an overinflated budget due 
to excessive contingency. In this case, 
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed 
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow 
was adjusted according to the new 
budget, the cashflow fell back into 
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered 
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system 
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the 
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these 
projects, once completed, will form part of the database 
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s 
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and 
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in 
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn. 
The mean project value is HKD 550m. 
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an 
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700 
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of 
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s 
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than 
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the 
delayed projects. 
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative 
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT 
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data, 
two methods were selected: tracking 
annual performance as a percentage 
of the (1) outturn performance and 
(2) the original plan. 
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the 
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a 
four-year project the first year would 
have 25% progress, the second 50% 
etc. 
The data for the analysis 
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the 
forecasted outcomes will be used 
in the future, so the dual reporting 
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most 
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random 
forrests, an artificial intelligence 
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to 
group the projects then extracted the 
typical cashflows from the s-curves 
and compared the fit of the curves. 
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had 
statistically significantly different 
outcomes. The analysis resulted in 
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the 
lines of building or non-building 
projects. Then the building projects 
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD 
150m or not and the non-building 
projects were categorised by whether 
the planned duration was less than 
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G 
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a 
warning flag status; red, amber or 
green based on the outcome of the 
project. If the project finished in the 
middle 40% of the historic projects 
(30th–70th percentile) the project 
got a green flag. The bottom and 
top 5% of the project got a red flag 
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other 
projects got an amber warning flag 
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning 
flag based on the project outcomes 
we trained three AI algorithms 
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the 
warning flag status based on progress 
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The 
algorithm looks at progress and then 
the share of dispensed cash to date 
The second AI assigns a 
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the 
share of dispensed cash and then at 
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate 
predictions in unseen test data. To 
validate the predictive power of the 
algorithm the data were split into a 
training and a test set. The AI learned 
from 70% of the data how to assign 
warning flags. Then the accuracy 
of the warning flags was measured 
on the remaining 30% of the data, 
which the algorithm had not seen 
before.
The AI achieves an excellent 
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The 
performance is well balanced across 
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags 
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that 
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost 
overrun the algorithm is accurate 
nearly 7 out of 10 times. 
The accuracy of the schedule 
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is 
accurate in its prediction 18%–63% 
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split 
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms 
randomness. If we simply made an 
uninformed “lucky” guess about the 
project’s risk we would get it right in 
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high 
risk category “red” the AI is more 
than 20–times better than a lucky 
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of 
the data, we tested how little data 
the AI needs to achieve this level of 
accuracy. The analysis shows that is 
possible with as little as 10% of the 
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that 
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we 
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early 
-warning-sign system needs some but 
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect; 
the accuracy is surpsingly good even 
though the algorithm only knew the 
cashflow and type of a project. 
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy

WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G 
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train 
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the 
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial 
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average 
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.

the AI algorithms was to predict the 
final outturn cost of projects.

achieved so far, measured against the 
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow 
spent to date as percentage of the 
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.

many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions, 
support vector machines, gradient 
boosters, random forrest regressions, 
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer 
percepetrons, simple deep neural 
networks and complex deep neural 
networks.
We measured the error of the 
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good 
the AI is at summarising the data it 
knows. We then gave the AI unseen 
data to test the prediction. As before, 
the AI used 70% of the data to train 
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural 
network. The mean squared error 
of the predictions for the test data

absolute error in the test data was 7.9 
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was 
within ±8% at the portfolio level. 
The mean squared error, which is 
similar to the standard deviation, is 
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions 
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95% 
of predictions are within a range 
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions 
are within ±4.8% of the predicted 
cost. The mean absolute error of the 
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an

error between ±3% and ±15%; to

error range, 100% of design needs to 
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to

falls within the range expected for a 
Class 1 cost estimate.

ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.

We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project 
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD

First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than 
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own 
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows

slowly than typical projects but it

flag for being very late if it can keep

a big cost underrun). 
Project 2 is progressing like a typical

AI raises questions about the plans 
after year 5.

AI assumes that the project will not 
follow its own forecasted trajectory 
but behave more like a typical project 
in the future. However, the unusual 
pattern of expenditure means that if 
the project does indeed accelerate its 
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn 
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn 
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s 
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true 
the AI forecasts spending of HKD 
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans 
include adding more detailed project data, further developing

(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy



L O O K I N G F O R W A R D
WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions
are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a
Class 1 cost estimate.




CASE STUDIES
SPOTTING RISK
ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.
THESE ARE TWO REAL-LIFE CASES WHERE THE AI SPOTTED RISKY
PROJECTS EARLY
We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD
1.3bn with a construction duration of 3.9 years. Project 1 has completed its first year of construction. Project 2
has completed its first two years of construction.
The latest cashflow information shows that project 1 has spent 1% of its cash and is nearly 29% complete when
measured against the originally planned duration. Project 2 is 51% complete and has spent 21% of its cash.
First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows
that this trend will reverse in the next
two years and exceed usual patterns
in years 4 and 5. The AI’s flag raises
questions about this unusual profile
of acceleration and suggests further
investigation.
Project 2 receives a yellow flag. The
project is spending its budget more
slowly than typical projects but it
forecasts that it will soon be in line
with others. The schedule flags show a similar pattern. Project 1 gets a red
flag for being very late if it can keep
up the expenditure as is (under the
assumption that this is not indicating
a big cost underrun).
Project 2 is progressing like a typical
project in Hong Kong and the AI assigned a green schedule flag. But the
AI raises questions about the plans
after year 5.
The AI also produces a cost forecast
of the final outturn cost. At the mo- ment Project 1 is forecasted to cost
HKD 4.0bn. For this estimate, the
AI assumes that the project will not
follow its own forecasted trajectory
but behave more like a typical project
in the future. However, the unusual
pattern of expenditure means that if
the project does indeed accelerate its
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true
the AI forecasts spending of HKD
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans
include adding more detailed project data, further developing
the AI to enhance the predictive power and extending the PSS to
railway projects in collaboration with other international regions. Our innovations will not only support Hong Kong’s ambitious vision but also benefit projects worldwide.

As a Masters degree student, YOu Have a project and the brief goes thus:


Component A is a team presentation of 25 minutes (with 5 minutes of questions).

As a group you will be required to create a PowerPoint presentation which will detail the planning and management issues of a global project.

1.Choose a project you know off or you are interested in provided it is global, whether completed or in progress, and make sure that you are able to gather the information that is necessary for your analysis;

This assessment strategy is employed to produce the type of output required by professional project management practice that is developed by a typical project team; and to maximize learning opportunities with added values for students’ development and character building.

This assignment requires you to develop research skills and find information that is useful for the purpose of detecting organizational issues related to the global environment and construct a plan. Your part of the project is to do the sessions 7 & 8; that is, Choose the way your teams will be creative (Brainstorming Techniques) and Describe the cultural differences and challenges in your project (Hofstede cultural scores)




The chosen global project is below, with all the information available.:

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS —
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to
HKD 325bn by 2031.
However, these projects are not without their problems.
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the
most significant initiatives in the world;
from the Olympics, the artificial island
of Lantau, to the International Space
Station.
One of the challenges currently
faced by project leaders and investors is
that projects do not perform well.
They underperform in terms
of execution, with significant cost and
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common.
Our research has shown this
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget,
over time, over and over again’.
This poor performance is not a
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly
consistent for over 70 years. It is also
common to different countries, sectors
and delivery in the private and public
sectors.
The scale of projects has been
increasing for decades. The largest
megaprojects have budgets that match
the gross domestic products of the largest countries.
The GDP of Hong Kong
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar
amount to the budget for China’s high
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This
large scale means that it is crucial for
the money spent on projects to be better
managed.
The impacts of funds of this
size being mismanaged can be felt on
a national and even international scale.
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects
under the Capital Works Programme
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects
required additional funding owing
to project specific circumstances, the
majority of approved projects were
delivered at or under the original
Approved Project Estimates (APE).
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the
projects and the amount represented
some 8% of the total provision of
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active
for the Industry, with approximately
850 Category A projects having their
final accounts settled. In terms of
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall
surplus of HKD 30bn.
Effectively, this means the
surplus generated at the portfolio
level was more than able to offset
the cost overruns incurred by a select
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong
is better than many other regions
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction
complexity as well as scale. They
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex
megaprojects in Hong Kong have
suffered from underperformance in
the form of delays, cost overruns
and/or quality failures in recent
years. These incidents have been
well documented through extensive
media coverage – leading to reduced
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project
are crucial and can set the tone and
influence its efficacy. One of the
challenges of project performance
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such
actions are undertaken, the harder
and more resource intensive it is to
rectify problems.
However, it is not always
easy to identify risky projects before
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared
to 2021. The Development Bureau
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery.
A key policy objective of the
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure
the effective planning, management
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and
works programmes in a safe, timely
and cost-effective manner and to
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack
the daily and deep involvement in
their projects. They need the right
monitoring tools and early-warning
-sign systems to help them in their
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these
projects, once completed, will form part of the database
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn.
The mean project value is HKD 550m.
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the
delayed projects.
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data,
two methods were selected: tracking
annual performance as a percentage
of the (1) outturn performance and
(2) the original plan.
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a
four-year project the first year would
have 25% progress, the second 50%
etc.
The data for the analysis
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the
forecasted outcomes will be used
in the future, so the dual reporting
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random
forrests, an artificial intelligence
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to
group the projects then extracted the
typical cashflows from the s-curves
and compared the fit of the curves.
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had
statistically significantly different
outcomes. The analysis resulted in
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the
lines of building or non-building
projects. Then the building projects
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD
150m or not and the non-building
projects were categorised by whether
the planned duration was less than
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy



L O O K I N G F O R W A R D
WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions
are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a
Class 1 cost estimate.




CASE STUDIES
SPOTTING RISK
ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.
THESE ARE TWO REAL-LIFE CASES WHERE THE AI SPOTTED RISKY
PROJECTS EARLY
We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD
1.3bn with a construction duration of 3.9 years. Project 1 has completed its first year of construction. Project 2
has completed its first two years of construction.
The latest cashflow information shows that project 1 has spent 1% of its cash and is nearly 29% complete when
measured against the originally planned duration. Project 2 is 51% complete and has spent 21% of its cash.
First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows
that this trend will reverse in the next
two years and exceed usual patterns
in years 4 and 5. The AI’s flag raises
questions about this unusual profile
of acceleration and suggests further
investigation.
Project 2 receives a yellow flag. The
project is spending its budget more
slowly than typical projects but it
forecasts that it will soon be in line
with others. The schedule flags show a similar pattern. Project 1 gets a red
flag for being very late if it can keep
up the expenditure as is (under the
assumption that this is not indicating
a big cost underrun).
Project 2 is progressing like a typical
project in Hong Kong and the AI assigned a green schedule flag. But the
AI raises questions about the plans
after year 5.
The AI also produces a cost forecast
of the final outturn cost. At the mo- ment Project 1 is forecasted to cost
HKD 4.0bn. For this estimate, the
AI assumes that the project will not
follow its own forecasted trajectory
but behave more like a typical project
in the future. However, the unusual
pattern of expenditure means that if
the project does indeed accelerate its
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true
the AI forecasts spending of HKD
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans
include adding more detailed project data, further developing
the AI to enhance the predictive power and extending the PSS to
railway projects in collaboration with other international regions. Our innovations will not only support Hong Kong’s ambitious vision but also benefit projects worldwide.
