THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.

RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy

the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had

spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.

The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions

of predictions are within a range

The AI estimate is in line

Association for the Advancement of

that international best practice for

error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow

be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a

The chosen global project is below, with all the information available.:

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS —
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to
HKD 325bn by 2031.
However, these projects are not without their problems.
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the
most significant initiatives in the world;
from the Olympics, the artificial island
of Lantau, to the International Space
Station.
One of the challenges currently
faced by project leaders and investors is
that projects do not perform well.
They underperform in terms
of execution, with significant cost and
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common.
Our research has shown this
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget,
over time, over and over again’.
This poor performance is not a
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly
consistent for over 70 years. It is also
common to different countries, sectors
and delivery in the private and public
sectors.
The scale of projects has been
increasing for decades. The largest
megaprojects have budgets that match
the gross domestic products of the largest countries.
The GDP of Hong Kong
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar
amount to the budget for China’s high
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This
large scale means that it is crucial for
the money spent on projects to be better
managed.
The impacts of funds of this
size being mismanaged can be felt on
a national and even international scale.
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects
under the Capital Works Programme
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects
required additional funding owing
to project specific circumstances, the
majority of approved projects were
delivered at or under the original
Approved Project Estimates (APE).
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the
projects and the amount represented
some 8% of the total provision of
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active
for the Industry, with approximately
850 Category A projects having their
final accounts settled. In terms of
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall
surplus of HKD 30bn.
Effectively, this means the
surplus generated at the portfolio
level was more than able to offset
the cost overruns incurred by a select
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong
is better than many other regions
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction
complexity as well as scale. They
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex
megaprojects in Hong Kong have
suffered from underperformance in
the form of delays, cost overruns
and/or quality failures in recent
years. These incidents have been
well documented through extensive
media coverage – leading to reduced
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project
are crucial and can set the tone and
influence its efficacy. One of the
challenges of project performance
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such
actions are undertaken, the harder
and more resource intensive it is to
rectify problems.
However, it is not always
easy to identify risky projects before
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared
to 2021. The Development Bureau
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery.
A key policy objective of the
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure
the effective planning, management
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and
works programmes in a safe, timely
and cost-effective manner and to
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack
the daily and deep involvement in
their projects. They need the right
monitoring tools and early-warning
-sign systems to help them in their
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these
projects, once completed, will form part of the database
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn.
The mean project value is HKD 550m.
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the
delayed projects.
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data,
two methods were selected: tracking
annual performance as a percentage
of the (1) outturn performance and
(2) the original plan.
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a
four-year project the first year would
have 25% progress, the second 50%
etc.
The data for the analysis
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the
forecasted outcomes will be used
in the future, so the dual reporting
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random
forrests, an artificial intelligence
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to
group the projects then extracted the
typical cashflows from the s-curves
and compared the fit of the curves.
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had
statistically significantly different
outcomes. The analysis resulted in
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the
lines of building or non-building
projects. Then the building projects
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD
150m or not and the non-building
projects were categorised by whether
the planned duration was less than
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy



L O O K I N G F O R W A R D
WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions
are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a
Class 1 cost estimate.




CASE STUDIES
SPOTTING RISK
ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.
THESE ARE TWO REAL-LIFE CASES WHERE THE AI SPOTTED RISKY
PROJECTS EARLY
We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD
1.3bn with a construction duration of 3.9 years. Project 1 has completed its first year of construction. Project 2
has completed its first two years of construction.
The latest cashflow information shows that project 1 has spent 1% of its cash and is nearly 29% complete when
measured against the originally planned duration. Project 2 is 51% complete and has spent 21% of its cash.
First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows
that this trend will reverse in the next
two years and exceed usual patterns
in years 4 and 5. The AI’s flag raises
questions about this unusual profile
of acceleration and suggests further
investigation.
Project 2 receives a yellow flag. The
project is spending its budget more
slowly than typical projects but it
forecasts that it will soon be in line
with others. The schedule flags show a similar pattern. Project 1 gets a red
flag for being very late if it can keep
up the expenditure as is (under the
assumption that this is not indicating
a big cost underrun).
Project 2 is progressing like a typical
project in Hong Kong and the AI assigned a green schedule flag. But the
AI raises questions about the plans
after year 5.
The AI also produces a cost forecast
of the final outturn cost. At the mo- ment Project 1 is forecasted to cost
HKD 4.0bn. For this estimate, the
AI assumes that the project will not
follow its own forecasted trajectory
but behave more like a typical project
in the future. However, the unusual
pattern of expenditure means that if
the project does indeed accelerate its
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true
the AI forecasts spending of HKD
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans
include adding more detailed project data, further developing
the AI to enhance the predictive power and extending the PSS to
railway projects in collaboration with other international regions. Our innovations will not only support Hong Kong’s ambitious vision but also benefit projects worldwide.

The chosen global project is below, with all the information available.:

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS —
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to
HKD 325bn by 2031.
However, these projects are not without their problems.
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the
most significant initiatives in the world;
from the Olympics, the artificial island
of Lantau, to the International Space
Station.
One of the challenges currently
faced by project leaders and investors is
that projects do not perform well.
They underperform in terms
of execution, with significant cost and
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common.
Our research has shown this
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget,
over time, over and over again’.
This poor performance is not a
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly
consistent for over 70 years. It is also
common to different countries, sectors
and delivery in the private and public
sectors.
The scale of projects has been
increasing for decades. The largest
megaprojects have budgets that match
the gross domestic products of the largest countries.
The GDP of Hong Kong
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar
amount to the budget for China’s high
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This
large scale means that it is crucial for
the money spent on projects to be better
managed.
The impacts of funds of this
size being mismanaged can be felt on
a national and even international scale.
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects
under the Capital Works Programme
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects
required additional funding owing
to project specific circumstances, the
majority of approved projects were
delivered at or under the original
Approved Project Estimates (APE).
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the
projects and the amount represented
some 8% of the total provision of
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active
for the Industry, with approximately
850 Category A projects having their
final accounts settled. In terms of
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall
surplus of HKD 30bn.
Effectively, this means the
surplus generated at the portfolio
level was more than able to offset
the cost overruns incurred by a select
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong
is better than many other regions
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction
complexity as well as scale. They
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex
megaprojects in Hong Kong have
suffered from underperformance in
the form of delays, cost overruns
and/or quality failures in recent
years. These incidents have been
well documented through extensive
media coverage – leading to reduced
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project
are crucial and can set the tone and
influence its efficacy. One of the
challenges of project performance
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such
actions are undertaken, the harder
and more resource intensive it is to
rectify problems.
However, it is not always
easy to identify risky projects before
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared
to 2021. The Development Bureau
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery.
A key policy objective of the
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure
the effective planning, management
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and
works programmes in a safe, timely
and cost-effective manner and to
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack
the daily and deep involvement in
their projects. They need the right
monitoring tools and early-warning
-sign systems to help them in their
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these
projects, once completed, will form part of the database
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn.
The mean project value is HKD 550m.
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the
delayed projects.
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data,
two methods were selected: tracking
annual performance as a percentage
of the (1) outturn performance and
(2) the original plan.
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a
four-year project the first year would
have 25% progress, the second 50%
etc.
The data for the analysis
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the
forecasted outcomes will be used
in the future, so the dual reporting
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random
forrests, an artificial intelligence
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to
group the projects then extracted the
typical cashflows from the s-curves
and compared the fit of the curves.
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had
statistically significantly different
outcomes. The analysis resulted in
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the
lines of building or non-building
projects. Then the building projects
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD
150m or not and the non-building
projects were categorised by whether
the planned duration was less than
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.

risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy

P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range

are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a

:- dynamic altura/1.
:- dynamic consecutivas/1.

:- use_module(library(clpfd)).

solicita_versao :-
    write('Escolha a versão do jogo: '), nl,
    write('1 - Normal'), nl,
    write('2 - Simplificada'), nl,
    read(Versao),
    valida_versao(Versao).

valida_versao(Versao) :-
    Versao < 1 ->
    write('Versão inválida. Tente novamente.'), nl,
    solicita_versao
    ;

    Versao > 2 ->
    write('Versão inválida. Tente novamente.'), nl,
    solicita_versao
    ;
    % armazena o valor da versao na variável global
    asserta(versao(Versao)).

solicita_largura :-
    write('Digite a quantidade de linhas: '), nl,
    read(Largura),
    valida_largura(Largura).

valida_largura(Largura) :-
    Largura < 1 ->
    write('Largura inválida. Tente novamente.'), nl,
    solicita_largura
    ;
    % armazena o valor da largura na variável global
    asserta(largura(Largura)).

solicita_altura :-
    write('Digite a quantidade de colunas: '), nl,
    read(Altura),
    valida_altura(Altura).

valida_altura(Altura) :-
    Altura < 1 ->
    write('Altura inválida. Tente novamente.'), nl,
    solicita_altura
    ;
    % armazena o valor da altura na variável global
    asserta(altura(Altura)).

solicita_consecutivas :-
    write('Digite a quantidade de peças repetidas para ganhar: '), nl,
    read(Consecutivas),
    valida_consecutivas(Consecutivas).

valida_consecutivas(Consecutivas) :-
    % armazena o valor da consecutivas na variável global
    asserta(consecutivas(Consecutivas)).

jogar :-
    % chama o predicado que solicita a versão
    solicita_versao,

    % chama o predicado que solicita a largura
    solicita_largura,

    % chama o predicado que solicita a altura
    solicita_altura,

    % chama o predicado que solicita os repetidas
    solicita_consecutivas,

    criar_tabuleiro(Tabuleiro),
    imprimir_tabuleiro(Tabuleiro),
    jogador1_joga(Tabuleiro).

% Cria um tabuleiro vazio com o tamanho especificado
criar_tabuleiro(Tabuleiro) :-
    largura(Largura),
    altura(Altura),
    criar_linhas(Largura, Altura, Tabuleiro).

criar_linhas(_, 0, []).
criar_linhas(Largura, Altura, [Linha|Tabuleiro]) :-
    Altura > 0,
    length(Linha, Largura),
    Altura1 is Altura - 1,
    criar_linhas(Largura, Altura1, Tabuleiro).

% Imprime o tabuleiro
imprimir_tabuleiro(Tabuleiro) :-
    imprimir_linhas(Tabuleiro).

% Funcoes auxiliares para imprimir o tabuleiro, linha por linha
imprimir_linhas([]).
imprimir_linhas([Linha|Tabuleiro]) :-
    write(' |'),
    imprimir_linha(Linha),
    write('|'),
    nl,
    imprimir_linhas(Tabuleiro).

imprimir_linha([]).
imprimir_linha([Celula|Linha]) :-
    (nonvar(Celula), write(Celula); write(' ')),
    write(' | '),
    imprimir_linha(Linha).

% função para substituir um elemento em uma posição específica
troca([Linha|Linhas], 1, Coluna, [NovaLinha|Linhas], Simbolo) :-
    troca_linha(Linha, Coluna, Simbolo, NovaLinha).
troca([Linha|Linhas], NumLinha, Coluna, [Linha|NovasLinhas], Simbolo) :-
    NumLinha > 1,
    NumLinha1 is NumLinha - 1,
    troca(Linhas, NumLinha1, Coluna, NovasLinhas, Simbolo).

% função para substituir um elemento em uma linha específica
troca_linha([_|Colunas], 1, Simbolo, [Simbolo|Colunas]).
troca_linha([Coluna|Colunas], NumColuna, Simbolo, [Coluna|NovasColunas]) :-
    NumColuna =\= 1,
    NumColuna1 is NumColuna - 1,
    troca_linha(Colunas, NumColuna1, Simbolo, NovasColunas).

% Jogador 1 joga
jogador1_joga(Tabuleiro) :-
    versao(Versao),
    largura(Largura),
    altura(Altura),

    write('Vez do Jogador 1 (X)'),nl,

    (Versao =:= 1) ->
    write('Escolha uma coluna: '),nl,
    read(Coluna),
    Coluna > 0, !,
    Coluna =< Largura, !,

    write('Escolha uma linha: '), nl,
    read(Linha1),
    Linha1 > 0, !,
    Linha1 =< Altura, !,

    criar_tabuleiro(NovoTabuleiro),
    troca(Tabuleiro, Linha1, Coluna, NovoTabuleiro, 'X'),
    imprimir_tabuleiro(NovoTabuleiro),
    jogador2_joga(NovoTabuleiro)

    ;
    (Versao =:= 2) ->
    write('Versão nao implementada'), nl.

jogador2_joga(Tabuleiro) :-

    write('Vez do Jogador 2 (O)'),nl,

    % Verifica versão do jogo
    (Versao =:= 1) ->

    troca(NovoTabuleiro, Linha, Coluna, TabuleiroMod),
    imprimir_tabuleiro(TabuleiroMod),

    ;
    (Versao =:= 2) ->

% Verifica se há um vencedor na horizontal
verificar_vitoria_horizontal(Tabuleiro, Peca) :-
    nth1(_, Tabuleiro, Linha),
    verificar_vitoria(Linha, Peca).

% Verifica se há um vencedor na vertical
verificar_vitoria_vertical(Tabuleiro, Peca) :-
    transpose(Tabuleiro, TabuleiroTransposto),
    verificar_vitoria_horizontal(TabuleiroTransposto, Peca).

% Verifica se há um vencedor na diagonal
verificar_vitoria_diagonal(Tabuleiro, Peca) :-
    diagonal(Tabuleiro, Diagonal),
    verificar_vitoria(Diagonal, Peca).

% Retorna a diagonal principal do tabuleiro
diagonal(Tabuleiro, Diagonal) :-
    diagonal(Tabuleiro, Diagonal, 1).

diagonal([], [], _).
diagonal([Linha|Tabuleiro], [Celula|Diagonal], N) :-
    nth1(N, Linha, Celula),
    N1 is N + 1,
    diagonal(Tabuleiro, Diagonal, N1).

% Verifica se há um vencedor em uma linha ou coluna
verificar_vitoria(Linha, Peca) :-
    consecutivas(Consecutivas),
    append(_, [Peca|T], Linha),
    length([Peca|T],Consecutivas),
    !.
verificar_vitoria(Linha, Peca) :-
    consecutivas(Consecutivas),
    append(T, [Peca|_], Linha),
    length(T, Consecutivas),
    !.

% Verifica se houve empate
empate(Tabuleiro) :-

% Verifica se todas as colunas foram preenchidas
todas_colunas_preenchidas([]).
todas_colunas_preenchidas([ColunaTabuleiro|Tabuleiro]) :-
    altura(Altura),
    length(ColunaTabuleiro, Altura),
    Altura > 0,
    todas_colunas_preenchidas(Tabuleiro).

venceu(Tabuleiro, Jogador) :-
    % verifica linhas
    member([Jogador,Jogador,Jogador], Tabuleiro),
    
    % verifica colunas
    transpose(Tabuleiro, Transposta),
    member([Jogador,Jogador,Jogador], Transposta),
    
    % verifica diagonal principal
    nth0(0, Tabuleiro, [Jogador,_,_]),
    nth0(1, Tabuleiro, [_,Jogador,_]),
    nth0(2, Tabuleiro, [_,_,Jogador]),
    
    % verifica diagonal secundária
    nth0(0, Tabuleiro, [_,_,Jogador]),
    nth0(1, Tabuleiro, [_,Jogador,_]),
    nth0(2, Tabuleiro, [Jogador,_,_]).

Eurocentrism- East and West: the two binaries
Eurocentrism can be defined as an epistemological framework that situates European culture, history, and values as the defining center of the world, while at the same time disregarding or belittling the contributions of other cultures and civilisations. This ethnocentric positioning perceives the Europe or West as a paragon of universal values and cultural superiority, leading to a systematic undervaluation and misrepresentation of non-European cultures. Consequently, Eurocentric discourse breeds a false dichotomy between the West and non-European societies, perpetuating the notion that the West is superior and in control of all areas of life, including social, political, cultural, scientific, military, and economic fields. Disparaging epithets are often attributed to the “non-West,” reinforcing connotations of inferiority, irrationality, belligerence, otherness, fanaticism, and barbarism in comparison to the West. This paradigm, therefore, not only consolidates the stature of the West, but also perpetuates the subordination of non-European societies within global power structures, and the spheres of knowledge and influence. This belief in Western superiority is often reinforced through various forms of discourse, including history, literature, art, music, etc. In a similar vein, through the utilization of Eurocentric and imperialistic perspectives, academic discourse has consistently depicted ‘Eastern societies’ as exotic and racialized, perpetuating a biased portrayal of the Orient or East. In his seminal text Orientalism (1979), Edward Said, a Palestinian critic, asserts that “European culture gained in strength and identity by setting itself off against the Orient as a sort of surrogate and even underground self.” (3) This dichotomy between the West and the East often presents the West as a modern, flowing territory and the East as a static, archaic region. Therefore, the Orient functions as a mirror to the West in that the West relies heavily on its counterpart, the Orient, for its own sense of superiority. (Sandy and Ouardi, 2019, p. 129) On the other hand, this discourse of exoticism, essentialism, and stereotyping of the East and its people has been used to justify colonization, exploitation, and violence against Eastern civilizations.

Eurocentrism: Hegemonic Dualism and Subaltern Marginalization

Eurocentrism is an ethnocentric epistemology prioritizing European culture, history, and values as the locus of global significance while diminishing non-European contributions. This paradigm fosters cultural hegemony whereby the West epitomizes universal values and sophistication, engendering a dichotomous relationship with non-European societies marked by the latter's systemic depreciation and misrepresentation. Consequently, Eurocentric discourse engenders pejorative connotations for the "non-West," positioning it as inferior, irrational, and barbaric vis-à-vis the West. This hegemonic dualism consolidates Western stature while perpetuating subaltern marginalization within global power structures and spheres of influence.

Western superiority is reinforced through various cultural discourses, including history, literature, and the arts. Similarly, academia often depicts "Eastern societies" as exotic and racialized, perpetuating Orientalist stereotypes. In Said's Orientalism (1979), he articulates the dichotomy between the West's self-perception as a progressive entity and the East as the stagnated, arcane other. The Orient thus mirrors the West as it relies on its counterpart for a sense of superiority (Sandy & Ouardi, 2019, p. 129). This essentialist and exoticized discourse functions to justify colonization, exploitation, and violence against Eastern civilizations.

In summary, Eurocentrism perpetuates a hegemonic dualism that prioritizes Western culture and values, while marginalizing non-European societies. Through various cultural discourses and academia, this paradigm fosters stereotypes and exoticization of non-Western societies, maintaining Western superiority and rationalizing colonial exploitation. The East, serving as a mirror to the West, allows for the consolidation of Western stature while subjugating and misrepresenting other civilizations.

Title: Unmasking Demosthenes: Lessons from Ender's Game for Today's Society

Introduction

In Orson Scott Card's renowned science-fiction novel, Ender's Game, one finds a futuristic world grappling with political unrest and an impending invasion by an alien species known as the "buggers." Amidst this backdrop of turmoil, Card cleverly narrates the story of two children, Peter and Valentine Wiggin, who rise to virtual power through the pseudonymous personas of Locke and Demosthenes, respectively. These anonymous characters embark on a journey through which they seek to influence public opinion, challenge the status quo, and question authority through their online writings. Of these, Demosthenes emerges as a figure bearing significant parallels to today's society, serving as a cautionary tale on the dangers of demagoguery, the power of the media, and the consequences of unchecked nationalism.

Demagoguery and Its Perils

In Card's novel, Demosthenes emerges as a poster child for demagoguery. He skillfully taps into the public's fears and uncertainties by preaching xenophobia, advocating for a strong defense against the "buggers," and critiquing political entities in power. Demosthenes' messages are often simplistic and focused on evoking intense emotional responses rather than promoting reasoned debate. 

This pattern of political discourse is all too familiar in today's society. Demagogues have risen to positions of power throughout human history. Today, some are quick to stoke the fires of fear and resentment, rallying support around overly simplistic solutions that often fail to deliver tangible outcomes. The rise of populism across various parts of the globe has signaled a retreat to nationalism and a push for exclusionary policies. Demosthenes serves as a stark reminder that societies must approach demagoguery with skepticism, resisting the urge to be swayed by emotional appeals devoid of reason or compassion.

The Power of the Media

The Internet plays a pivotal role in Ender's Game, as it does in our own lives today. Peter and Valentine – as Locke and Demosthenes – dominate the virtual world and master the art of manipulating public opinion. In this fictional universe, the power of words and ideas disseminated through the electronic media proves awe-inspiring, a power that has grown exponentially in our own reality.

The parallels between the novel's virtual world and today's social media landscape are uncanny. The digital age has expanded the reach and swiftness of public discourse, making it susceptible to manipulation by skillful actors. The spread of fake news and the rise of echo chambers have exacerbated divisions in society, eroding trust in institutions and leaving the public ever more vulnerable to the tactics of demagogues. Demosthenes' ascent in Ender's Game highlights the importance of vigilance and critical thinking in today's age of information deluge.

The Consequences of Unchecked Nationalism

Throughout his writings, Demosthenes preaches a hardline nationalism, a passion that finds fertile ground in a society scarred by fear and the prospect of an alien invasion. This sentiment resonates with the people, propelling Demosthenes into a position of immense influence. 

This relentless pursuit of nationalism in the novel serves as a cautionary tale for our own society. In recent years, we have witnessed a resurgence of nationalist sentiments, with political actors harnessing such emotions to advance their own agendas. However, unchecked nationalism often carries with it a risk of exclusion, discrimination, and potentially even violence. By drawing parallels with Demosthenes, Card's novel urges societies to recognize the potential harm of embracing nationalism without sufficiently accounting for the moral and social implications it might entail.

Conclusion

Ender's Game may be set in a fictional future, but the figure of Demosthenes holds significant relevance for our own society. Demosthenes represents a chilling cautionary tale, offering insight into the dangers of demagoguery, the power of the media, and the consequences of unchecked nationalism. As we navigate our own uncertain times, it is vital to remember the lessons from this iconic figure: to approach demagoguery with skepticism, to critically engage with and scrutinize the information we consume, and to carefully consider the implications of the ideologies we choose to embrace.

Agatha Christie ist zweifellos eine der berühmtesten Schriftstellerinnen des Kriminalgenres und eine Legende in der Literaturgeschichte. Sie wird auch oft als 'Queen of Crime' bezeichnet und ihre Krimiromane haben eine immens beliebte Fangemeinde auf der ganzen Welt. Mit mehr als 80 Romanen, Kurzgeschichten und Theatertexten, die in mehr als 50 Sprachen übersetzt wurden, hat sie sich als eine der produktivsten Schriftstellerinnen des 20. Jahrhunderts etabliert. Aber was ist das Geheimnis ihres Schreibstils und warum hat sie so viele Fans?

Agatha Christies Schreibstil ist bekannt für seine Komplexität und Detailtiefe. Sie hat während ihrer Karriere eine Vielzahl von technischen Aspekten des Schreibens angewendet, um ihre Charaktere und ihre Geschichten auf unterschiedlichste Weise zu präsentieren. Ein bekanntes Merkmal ihres Schreibstils ist die Verwendung von Schwerkraft - das bedeutet, dass sie den Leser dazu bringen wollte, die Geschichte so aufmerksam zu lesen, dass sich der Leser ein Bild von der Lösung des Falls machen konnte, bevor der Detektiv in der Geschichte es tat. Das ist ein technisches Manöver, das normalerweise funktioniert, da es den Leser dazu zwingt, die Handlung zu verfolgen und die Hinweise auf die wahre Natur des Falles zu suchen. Dies verbindet die Leserdinglichkeit und emotional mit den Charakteren und schafft eine hochwertige Lektüreerfahrung.

Agatha Christies Schreibstil ist auch bekannt für seine schnörkellose und präzise Sprache. Sie vermeidet es oft, ausschweifende Beschreibungen von Charakteren, Plätzen oder Szenen zu verwenden, und statt dessen legt sie Wert auf die Kürze und Klarheit von Informationen in der Handlung. Dies ermöglicht es ihr, den Leser konzentriert auf die Handlung zu halten, während er sich darauf konzentriert, die Hinweise zusammenzuführen und die Lösung des Falls zu suchen.

Ein anderer wichtiger Aspekt von Agatha Christies Schreibstil ist ihre Fähigkeit, unterschiedliche Charaktere und Perspektiven einzufangen. Sie verwendet verschiedene Methoden, um Farbe und Tiefe in die Charaktere und ihre Geschichten zu bringen. Sie schickt ihre Charaktere durch ein Labyrinth von menschlichen Emotionen und Beziehungen, in dem sie oft mit früheren Verfehlungen konfrontiert werden. Diese Konfrontationen führen oft zu entscheidenden Momenten in der Geschichte, in denen der Leser etwas erfahren kann, das zum Verständnis und zur Lösung des Rätsels beiträgt. Agatha Christie nutzt auch ihre Fähigkeit, verschiedene Perspektiven und Standpunkte einzubeziehen, um die Figuren in ihren Geschichten in ein breiteres soziales Umfeld zu erweitern, was dazu beiträgt, das Mysterium und den Neidfaktor der Geschichte zu vergrößern.

Ein weiteres wichtiges Merkmal von Agatha Christies Schreibstil ist ihre Fähigkeit, das Genre des Kriminalromans zu erweitern. Die meisten ihrer Werke sind tatsächlich mehr als einfache Detektivgeschichten. Sie integriert oft spezielle Aspekte des menschlichen Verhaltens und der Psychologie in ihre Geschichten und nutzt diese Merkmale, um den Leser tief in die Handlung zu ziehen. Sie sorgte auch dafür, dass ihre Charaktere nicht an die in Kriminalliteratur und Filmen üblichen Klischees gebunden waren. Sie verstand, dass die Charaktere in ihren Geschichten komplex und vielschichtig sein mussten, um den Leser hinzuhalten und seinen Interesse aufrechtzuerhalten. Dies verleiht ihren Geschichten ein besonderes Maß an Authentizität und Glaubwürdigkeit, was dazu beiträgt, dass sich der Leser emotional zu den Charakteren hingezogen fühlt.

Schließlich war Agatha Christie auch bekannt für ihre Fähigkeit, ihre Leser zu überraschen. Sie legte immer wieder falsche Fährten und führte ihre Leser oft auf die falsche Fährte in Bezug auf die Identität des Täters oder die Lösung des Falles. Dies ist eines der Markenzeichen ihres Schreibstils und trug auch erheblich zu ihrer Beliebtheit und Legendenbildung bei.

Wie man sehen kann, ist Agatha Christies Schreibstil komplex und vielfältig. Sie verwendete eine Vielzahl von Techniken, um ihre Geschichten und Charaktere möglichst genau aufzustellen und ihre Leser in ihren Bann zu ziehen. Ihre Fähigkeit, das Genre des Kriminalromans zu erweitern und ihren Lesern ein authentisches Erlebnis zu bieten, hat dazu beigetragen, ihre Geschichten zeitlos zu machen und sie bis heute für Liebhaber des Genres interessant zu halten.

Insgesamt bleibt Agatha Christie eine Ikone der Literatur, die aus gutem Grund so viele Fans hat. Ihre Bücher sind für jeden Liebhaber des Kriminalgenres ein Muss und ihr Einfluss lässt sich in vielen modernen Kriminalgeschichten und Fernsehserien immer noch spüren. Ihr Schreibstil hat uns gelehrt, wie man komplexe und vielfältige Charaktere und Geschichten schreibt, die uns emotional auf Touren bringen und uns in die Tiefen unseres Verstandes ziehen.

Point of View and the Rendering of Child Consciousness in the Initial Chapters of A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man: A Theoretical and Textual Exploration

Prolegomenon

James Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man is hailed as a seminal Bildungsroman, tracing the trajectory of a young artist's unfolding sensibility, as evidenced in the realm of aesthetic, intellectual, and religious introspection. This essay is chiefly concerned with examining the literary techniques that have enabled the novel to render, in a syntactically adroit and pragmatically nuanced manner, the child consciousness of Stephen Dedalus in the initial chapters, with a specific focus on the narrative point of view. Employing an eclectic theoretical framework which draws upon structuralist, phenomenological, and existential theories, this essay will critically appraise the constitutive role of language, temporality, and memory in the formation of a nascent artistic subjectivity.

1. Temporality, Memory, and the Emergence of Child Consciousness in A Portrait

One of the foremost linguistic markers of child consciousness in A Portrait lies in its temporal structuration. Structuralist critics such as Ricœur and Genette have speculated upon the linear imprint of chronological time on the human psyche, observing that a child's cognitive horizons are largely circumscribed by the temporal and spatial demarcations engendered by their lived experiences (Ricœur 1984, Genette 1980). In the case of the young Stephen Dedalus, his perceptual world is transfigured by his naissance into a temporal ethology of a fragmented and rotational nature. In the first chapter, this temporal vector is exhibited in Stephen's recounting of his father's story: "but today as he bent the letter that's father's second name because Dante had two brushes in her press" (Joyce 1916, p.9). The overlapping temporal brackets of the "past" (father's story), "present" (Dante), and "future" (Dante's brushes) signify the enmeshment of the character's consciousness in the realm of simultaneity, as opposed to a linear and causal mapping of experiences (Ricœur 1984, p.52).

Memory, the faculty of mental time travel, serves to deepen this initial impression of temporality in the embryonic consciousness of Stephen. Memory not only evokes a storehouse of images for the emerging artist but also constructs a hermeneutic and dialectical framework that engages Stephen's identity through the interplay between recollection and forgetfulness. The phenomenologist Edmund Husserl argues that memory's capacity to elicit dormant impressions from their subjective substratum, effecting a transcendent gaze beyond the immediate horizon of the world, finds expression in Joyce's aesthetic method of "epiphany" (Husserl 1991, p.126; Joyce 1916, p.83). This interplay of presence and absence in memory is evident in the scene where Stephen remembers his exchange with Dante and Uncle Charles:

"I will not apologise, uncle. I will not apologise.

- Are you afraid, Simon?

- Afraid?

- Ay, afraid of your life." (Joyce 1916, p.30)

Wrapped in the shroud of a profound Biblical allusion (the story of Peter denying Christ thrice before the cock crows), this memory evokes the act of defiance on the part of the young protagonist while simultaneously exposing the child consciousness of the still-forming artist.

2. Language and the Making of an Artistic Subjectivity in the Initial Chapters

The trajectory from child consciousness to maturity in A Portrait is inextricably linked with Stephen Dedalus's journey towards linguistic and cognitive maturation. As a subject within the domestic and scholastic settings, language serves as both a prison house for Stephen as well as a medium of transcendence (Manguel 1997, pp.12-18). From his father's bawdy lines at the Christmas dinner to Friar Gorman's catechesis, Stephen's sensibility is caught in the net of societal language, inherited semantic traditions, and ideological dogma.

The most prominent marker of child consciousness or the lack thereof in A Portrait is the evolving relationship between Stephen and language. In the initial stages, Stephen's linguistic comprehension is inchoate and fragmentary, with phrases such as "the eagles will come and pull out his eyes" denoting a fractured grasp of meaning (Joyce 1916, p.8). While the young Stephen struggles with the ideographic significance of language, he demonstrates an incipient affinity for its acoustic properties, the musicality of words, and their rhythmic vitality. This is evidenced in his enigmatic musing on the onomatopoeic quality of words such as pusheen and tuckoo: "that was the green: and that was the quiet" (Joyce 1916, p.7). The child consciousness is further articulated through Stephen's penchant for the assimilation of newfangled terms, such as "suck" and "aignorance" - malapropisms calling attention to his developing linguistic repertoire and imbuing the novel with a linguistic vertiginosity (Joyce 1916, p.15, p.21).

3. The Point of View and the Stream of Consciousness Technique in the Initial Chapters

The stream-of-consciousness technique, pioneered by Joyce, externalises the free associative logic of a mind in quest of meaning, outside the rational dictates of logocentric discourse (Humphrey 1954, p.31). Adapting this revolutionary narrative perspective, A Portrait captures the child consciousness of Stephen Dedalus, navigating a labyrinth of memories, perceptions, and fleeting impressions. The stream of consciousness technique lends credence to the phenomenological interiority of Stephen's world, providing the reader with an intimate and unmediated access to his consciousness. This empathic leap into the psychic recesses of the character permits the reader to appreciate the symbolic and affective dimensions of his world, the parallax of sensations and memories that condition his intellectual and artistic gestation.

In A Portrait, this narrative mode not only portrays the kaleidoscope of Stephen's thought processes but also delineates various spatial, temporal, and thematic registers, ultimately metamorphosing into a quasi-Bakhtinian heteroglossia (Bakhtin 1981, p.278). The amalgamation of indirect interior monologues, first-person narration, and social dialects marks the novel's text with a palimpsestic layering, particularly evident in these initial chapters. The dinner table scene, for example, portrays an intricate interweaving of voices, including the ethnocentric discourse of Mr. Casey, the feminist rhetoric of Dante, and more subdued voices such as Uncle Charles, all represented within the novel's polysemic tapestry.

Coda

To summarise, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man excavates the realm of child consciousness through a deft interweaving of temporality, memory, language, and narrative perspective. The novel's linguistic finesse and syntactic dexterity cast light on the evolution of Stephen Dedalus's sensibility, revealing the vicissitudes of his existential journey and his quest for consummate self-expression. By exploring the dialectics between impersonal and personal memory, pre-existing narrative structures and ecstasies of linguistic innovation, Joyce's A Portrait remains an evocative chronicle of a young artist's path to self-awareness and his creative epiphanies.

In conclusion, James Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man serves as a testament to literature's power to evoke the complexity and depth of human consciousness, particularly that of a young artist blossoming into maturity. Through its nuanced exploration of temporality, memory, linguistic mastery, and narrative techniques, the novel paints a vivid portrait of Stephen Dedalus's evolving consciousness and his ultimate pursuit of artistic authenticity.

In doing so, Joyce not only crafted an enduring work of literary art but also contributed significantly to our understanding of the human psyche and the dynamics of creative growth. The lyrical intertwining of diverse voices and perspectives within the narrative landscape enriches both the text and the reader's experience, painting a multifaceted portrait that transcends static representations and defies simplistic analysis. The novel remains a monumental achievement in the annals of literary history and a compelling exploration of the intricate tapestry of human consciousness.

Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man leaves an indelible mark on both the literary landscape and the reader's psyche by illuminating the multifarious aspects of human consciousness and creative maturation. Through its innovative narrative techniques and intricate depiction of the evolving sensibilities of its protagonist, the novel offers a window into the complexities of the human mind and the myriad influences that contribute to the formulation of artistic identity.

By engaging readers in a deeply immersive exploration of Stephen Dedalus's world and the variegated contours of his consciousness, the novel offers insights into the universal human experience of growth, transformation, and the undying quest for self-realization. As such, it serves as a touchstone for future generations of readers and writers to draw inspiration and wisdom from the unparalleled richness of its evocative narrative and the profundity of its portrayal of the artist's journey toward authenticity and self-expression.

Ultimately, A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man stands as a testament to the enduring power and significance of literature as an unparalleled medium for capturing the intricacies of human experience and the ever-changing landscapes of our innermost thoughts, emotions, and aspirations. Joyce's seminal Bildungsroman thus remains a salient chronicle of artistic self-discovery and a lodestar for discerning readers seeking an enlightening, exhilarating journey into the depths of human consciousness and the inexhaustible potential of the creative spirit.

conversation.content: does the winner-take-all system affect politiacl parties

Yes, the winner-take-all system can have a significant impact on political parties. In a winner-take-all system, the candidate who receives the most votes in an election wins the entire election, with no proportional representation for the losing candidate or party. 

This can make it difficult for third parties to gain any traction, as they often don't have enough support to win an entire election. As a result, third parties are often ignored or dismissed by the media and the public. 

In a two-party system, the winner-take-all system can also lead to polarization and gridlock, as each major party tries to win control of the government rather than working together to find compromise solutions. This can make it difficult for the government to address major issues facing the country. 

Overall, the winner-take-all system can have a major impact on political parties, and it's one of the factors that contributes to the two-party system in the United States.
can congress issue fines to the bureaucracy

Congress has the power to authorize fines against individuals or organizations for violating federal laws, but it generally does not have the power to directly issue fines to the bureaucracy. Rather, agencies and bureaucrats are subject to fines and penalties through the agencies' specific statutory and regulatory authority, as well as through court-imposed penalties resulting from legal action taken against those agencies by Congress or affected parties.

Congress can, however, indirectly influence agency behavior through the appropriations process by withholding agency funds or imposing budget restrictions if the agency fails to perform its duties or comply with certain requirements. Additionally, Congress can use its oversight powers to investigate agency activities and compel agency compliance with statutory requirements, and can hold agency officials accountable through the impeachment and removal process.
how can congress control the bureaucracy

Congress can control the bureaucracy in several ways. Here are some examples:

1. Authorization and Appropriation: Congress has the power to authorize and appropriate funds for government agencies. The authorization process involves setting policy goals and objectives for agencies while the appropriation process determines how much funding is provided to implement those goals. Congress can use both to influence agencies, agencies that do not comply with Congress's intentions can face a reduction in their funding.

2. Oversight: Congress has a broad oversight role over the bureaucracy that includes conducting investigations, holding hearings, and calling agency officials to testify before Congressional committees. Congress can use information obtained from these investigations to force the bureaucracy to take actions or change specific policies.

3. Legislation: Congress can pass legislation that tells the bureaucracy what it can and cannot do. Statutes set forth the specific policy objectives that the bureaucracy is intended to implement, and Congress can impose mandates, limits, controls or requirements that agencies have to follow. 

4. Confirmation Power: Congress has the power of confirmation over many executive branch officials, including agency heads. Congress can influence agency policy by choosing to confirm, or not, nominees for certain positions.

5. Impeachment: Congress can remove appointed officials from office through impeachment, and has occasionally used this power to remove top bureaucrats.

Overall, Congress's power to control the bureaucracy derives from its constitutional authority to regulate commerce and make laws, its power of the purse, and its power to investigate and legislate.
